TAKES BIG TRIP TO SEE DODGERS; Having traveled nearly half way around the world to see his first professional baseball game and to study American sports, Abd Traboulsi, Director of Athletics at the American University of Beirut, Lebanon, was the guest of Branch Rickey June 20 when the Brooklyn Dodgers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates. Other guests at the game were Commissioner "Happy" Chandler and Ford Frick, President of the National League. Mr. Traboulsi who hopes eventually to introduce American baseball to his native Lebanon, plans to spend the summer at Ann Arbor taking a course for physical directors at the University of Michigan. With the American University of Beirut for 20 years, Mr. Traboulsi has charge of the athletic program for 2500 students representing 40 nationalities comprising the largest American university overseas. The American University of Beirut is a member of the Near East College Association of which Lowell Thomas is National Chairman and Allen Dulles, President of the Board of Directors. Photo shows: (left to right: Red Barber, Mr. Traboulsi, Commissioner Chandler and Mr. Rickey

Announcement of gifts of $1,000,000 toward the three-year goal of $15,000,000 to rehabilitate and expand the eight members of the Near East College Association was made by Lowell Thomas, fund chairman, tonight at a dinner honoring Dr. Allen O. Whipple, eminent American Surgeon. Dr. Whipple leaves for Lebanon shortly as advisor to the new Dodge Medical Center of the American University of Beirut, one of the largest single objectives of the fund. Dr. Whipple, retiring this year from Columbia University and Presbyterian Hospital, received tributes for his career in medicine from many persons of prominence at the dinner attended by Hon. Joseph C. Grew, Former Undersecretary of State; Madame Bechara El-Khouri, wife of the President of Lebanon; Allen W. Dulles, President of the Near East College Association; George Wadsworth, U.S. Minister to Syria and Lebanon; Photo Gratis for immediate release courtesy fund for Near East College Assn. ; Photo shows: Left to right, Dr. Allen O. Whipple, Joseph C. Grew, Allen W. Dulles and Lowell Thomas.

SALUTE TO SARNOFF More than 1,000 leaders of science, industry, government and religion gathered in New York tonight (Sept. 30) for an unprecedented salute to Gen. David Sarnoff, father of American television and chairman of the Radio Corporation of America. Gen. Sarnoff, who started his communications career on Sept. 30, 1906 as an office boy for the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company of America, was honored with a 60th anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Three national organizations - Electronic Industries Association (EIA), the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and the National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) - joined forces to co-sponsor the "Salute to David Sarnoff." Gen. Sarnoff receives a gold medallion from toastmaster Lowell Thomas, while Vincent Wasilewski, president of NAB, holds a scroll citing Sarnoff accomplishments. At right is Frederick R. Kappel, chairman, American Telephone and Telegraph Company. At rear, from left, are Dr. Jerome Wiesner, provost and dean of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, representing IEEE; William S. Paley, chairman, Columbia Broadcasting System, representing NAB; and Walter K. MacAdam, vice president of IEEE. Altho' LT had left N.B.C. and gone over to CBS 20 years before this event Gen. Sarnoff asked him to be the toastmaster.

Note: SALUTE TO SARNOFF More than 1,000 leaders of science, industry, government and religion gathered in New York tonight (Sept. 30) for an unprecedented salute to Gen. David Sarnoff, father of American television and chairman of the Radio Corporation of America. Gen. Sarnoff, who started his communications career on Sept. 30, 1906 as an office boy for the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company of America, was honored with a 60th anniversary dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Three national organizations - Electronic Industries Association (EIA), the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), and the National Association of Broadcasters (NAB) - joined forces to co-sponsor the "Salute to David Sarnoff." Gen. Sarnoff receives a gold medallion from toastmaster Lowell Thomas, while Vincent Wasilewski, president of NAB, holds a scroll citing Sarnoff accomplishments. At right is Frederick R. Kappel, chairman, American Telephone and Telegraph Company. At rear, from left, are Dr. Jerome Wiesner, provost and dean of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, representing IEEE; William S. Paley, chairman, Columbia Broadcasting System, representing NAB; and Walter K. MacAdam, vice president of IEEE. Altho' LT had left N.B.C. and gone over to CBS 20 years before this event Gen. Sarnoff asked him to be the toastmaster.

Caption: (MH1) MIAMI, April 14 -- GETTING TO THE SEAT OF THE PROBLEM -- Mohan, a 1,500 pound baby rhinocerous from Nepal, starred in a Lowell Thomas film and then was donated to the Crandon Park Zoo in Miami. Thomas, a world-famed newscaster, showed up with a bunch of greenery for Mohan during a visit to Miami. But Mohan showed his gratitude by biting Thomas on the seat of the pants. 1971

LOWELL THOMAS RECEIVES AMERICAN LEGION PUBLIC RELATIONS AWARD - Veteran reporter and commentator Lowell Thomas is presented the 1972 American Legion National Commander's Public Relations Award by National Commander John H. Geiger, of Des Plaines, Ill., at the Legion's annual Public Relations Luncheon held March 1, 1972. Newsman Thomas was cited for "his pioneering efforts in the audio visual field as a commentator and lecturer on our world" and for bringing to the people of the world "a greater understanding of diverse lands and cultures." The Legion's Public Relations Luncheon was held in conjunction with the organization's 12th annual Washington Conference, February 27 - March 3. Shown Left to Right are: National Commander John H. Geiger; Auxiliary National President Bertha Parker; Lowell Thomas; U.S. Secret Service Director, James J. Rowley; Legion National Adjutant, William F. Hauck

Lowell Thomas Honored by his college fraternity Lowell Thomas, famous author, news commentator and world traveler, smiles happily after receiving the 1938 Man of the Year Award from his college fraternity, Kappa Sigma. The presentation was made Friday evening, December 9, before 300 members of the fraternity at the Merchants and Manufacturers Club in Chicago. Hill Blackett, Chicago and New York advertising agency president, made the presentation, and Wesley W. Kergan, San Francisco attorney and Worthy Grand Scribe of Kappa Sigma, registers an expression of satisfaction as the fraternity has singled out another of its members for honor. Thomas was given this award after nation-wide balloting for his iron man feats as an author, adventurer and consistent accuracy in news commentating for over eight years on radio and screen.

Verso: Lowell Thomas Honored by his college fraternity Lowell Thomas, famous author, news commentator and world traveler, smiles happily after receiving the 1938 Man of the Year Award from his college fraternity, Kappa Sigma. LOWELL THOMAS RECEIVES AMERICAN LEGION PUBLIC RELATIONS AWARD - Veteran reporter and commentator Lowell Thomas is presented the 1972 American Legion National Commander's Public Relations Award by National Commander John H. Geiger, of Des Plaines, Ill., at the Legion's annual Public Relations Luncheon held March 1, 1972. Newsman Thomas was cited for "his pioneering efforts in the audio visual field as a commentator and lecturer on our world" and for bringing to the people of the world "a greater understanding of diverse lands and cultures." The Legion's Public Relations Luncheon was held in conjunction with the organization's 12th annual Washington Conference, February 27 - March 3. L to R: James Rowley, Director, U.S. Secret Service; Lowell Thomas

World Adventure Series, Detroit, George F. Pierrot Lowell Thomas, principal speaker at a 1973 Detroit Press Club dinner commemorating the 40th birthday of the World Adventure Series, greets his friend George Pierrot, who founded the Series at Detroit's civic art museum in 1933. Thomas has been a member of the Series Board of Directors since its founding. Thomas, in behalf of friends and associates, presented Pierrot the portrait shown in the background, painted by the noted artist John Coppin. The World Adventure Series pioneered travel-adventure color movies in auditoriums and on television and has won many world-wide awards. The Detroit Press Club dinner was arranged by Leonard R. Barnes, author, world traveler and editor of Michigan AAA's monthly travel magazine, MICHIGAN LIVING

Subject files: President Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Lowell Thomas

Caption: August 21, 1938. SENATOR POPE GUEST AT SUMMER WHITE HOUSE. Pawling, N.Y. - President Roosevelt with Sen. James P. Pope (left), administration supporter recently defeated in the Idaho primaries for re-nomination, as they watched a game between Lowell Thomas's "Nine Old Men" and the "White House Purgers" here, August 21. Senator Pope may run as an independent. He told newsmen he and the President touched briefly on the possibility of his re-entering the field

Note: DEFEATED IDAHO SENATOR DISCUSSES FUTURE PLANS WITH THE PRESIDENT, HYDE PARK, N.Y. - Lowell Thomas, author and radio commentator; Senator James J. Pope of Idaho, and President Roosevelt, photographed (left to right) after attending a baseball game between Mr. Thomas's "Nine Old Men," and the "New Deal Purgers," composed of White House correspondents, photographers and Secret Service Agents, near here on August 21. Both before and after the game, the Chief Executive and the Senator conferred on the advisability of the latter running independently against Representative D. Worth Clark, the choice of the Democratic Party for Senate
[left to right: Senator James P. Pope, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, Lowell Thomas]

Caption: August 21, 1938. THE PRESIDENT IS SERENADED. Pawling, N.Y. - A feature of the soft ball game here, Aug. 21, between Lowell Thomas's "Nine Old Men" and the "White House Purgers" , consisting of correspondents, cameramen, and secret service operatives, was this hillbilly band [Maine Lumberjacks]. They are shown here demonstrating their talents for President Roosevelt who also witnessed the ball game. Standing by in bathing suit is Lowell Thomas
[Franklin Delano Roosevelt in car with Lowell Thomas and musicians]
[Franklin Delano Roosevelt in car with Lowell Thomas and musicians]
Spectators at Nine Old Men, White House Purgers game, Right to left, Eleanor Roosevelt, Cynic [Westbrook] Pegler, George Bye, Ty Cobb

Note: A group of unknown* spectators wildly applauding one of the Nine Old Men, in the annual game with the White House Purgers. *Right to left: The First Lady, Cynic [Westbrook] Pegler, Softball Manager George Bye, and Deems (Ty Cobb) Taylor

Subject files: Salute to Lowell Thomas dinner

Note: SALUTE TO LOWELL THOMAS - NEW YORK: At a ceremony held at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel here Lowell Thomas was presented with the New York City Bronze Medal. Among those present were: Governor [Nelson] Rockefeller, Thomas Dewey, Edward Sweeney, President of The Explorers Club; Richard Patterson, NYC Chief of Protocol; James G. Stahlman, publisher of the Nashville Banner; and Colonel Bernt Balchen, Arctic flier (11/22/1965)
